Subject: Graphics processing units and NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=292213213; y=Y4EiICXemlYsZjT4dOXOFDac1bbLdNUjRyEkXpAl-ok7WKnnFng4FTyiPgE

Hi,

This isn't really specific to NEAT but I am not working with any other=

ANN technology right now.

I was talking to some colleagues that are worki=
ng in industry right
now producing a physics processing unit. They mentione=
d that people
are using the Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) in high end vi=
deo cards
for doing highly parallelized processing of data.

I did some res=
earch and NVIDIA has released a library called CUDA for
interfacing with th=
eir cards and doing non-graphics specific work. It
is aimed at people doing=
 simulations or anything that requires (or
benefits from ) a high degree of=
 parallelization. It works under both
Linux and Windows. It allows Sparse M=
atrix Multiplication (SMM).
Apparently ANN's can be represented as a matrix=
 then evaluated with SMM. 

This could allow us to do highly parallelized e=
valuation of networks.
All on one machine without a cluster. Or you could u=
se this in
conjunction with a cluster to get some really amazing performanc=
e
increases. From talking to my colleagues and discussing the problem
they =
figure if implemented right I could gain a 20 fold improvement in
the perfo=
rmance of evaluating larger networks (100+ neurons). For
smaller networks t=
here would be few performance gains.

I would love to work on this problem =
with anyone else who is
interested. I want to produce a C++ library that co=
uld be called from
the C# or other c++ implementations for evaluating ANNs =
in a highly
parallel fashion.

Anyone want to work on it with me? It is a l=
ittle more than I have
energy to take on all by myself right now. I am jugg=
ling a few other
balls (who isn't).

Thanks,

Shane
